definition:
We will show how to compute the last non-zero digit of the factorial of
a number from its digits without having to compute the factorial itself.

Let $L(n)$ denote the last non-zero digit of $n$ in base 10. We note
some basic properties of $L$ which can easily be checked:

-   For all $n$, we have $L(10n) = L(n)$.

-   If $L(m) \neq 5$ and $L(n) \neq 5$, then $L(mn) = L (L(m) L(n))$.

We also tabulate the values of $L(n!)$ for small values of $n$:
$$\begin{aligned}
L(0!) &=& 1 \\
L(1!) &=& 1 \\
L(2!) &=& 2 \\
L(3!) &=& 6 \\
L(4!) &=& 4 \\
L(5!) &=& 2 \\
L(6!) &=& 2 \\
L(7!) &=& 4 \\
L(8!) &=& 2 \\
L(9!) &=& 8 \\
L(10!) &=& 8 \end{aligned}$$

Next, we make two less trivial observations:

For all positive integers $n$, we have $L(n!) \neq 5$.
